and Amazon to meet with an unusual pair
of activists fighting to preserve the
rainforest
there's a small monkey this is one sees
an indigenous Amazonian and member of
the board of directors of the Etana
foundation that's an organization
dedicated to preserving the rainforests
by sustaining the people in it one grew
up using poison darts and a blowgun to
hunt for food his home village of just
five families was so remote it was a
five hour walk to his neighbor's before
you were 17 had you ever had you ever
seen electricity
had you ever worn shoes you know have
you ever seen running water no never
by the time one was 17
his older brother had already left the
jungle 13 years ago Juan decided to
visit him and on the way he passed
through a town those are the first time
getting out of my village I had to walk
like three days and then I took a plane
that was my first time flying and when
you got on the plane were you barefoot
or well my brother sent it to me a pair
of shoes and then I had to come it was
really actually weird you know I was
wearing that and I was like kind of
walking now with the heavy shoes like
this it was you know really you know
interesting at the same time as you're
saying overwhelming you know for me
being in a city one ended up working at
an eco lodge in the Amazon the lodge was
run by a Kentuckian Douglas mcmechen in
the United States Douglas had been a
successful entrepreneur with millions
invested in various ventures but just as
he was entering middle age he lost
everything when he went bankrupt in the
1982 recession so you're in your early
40s and your business goes bust you go
bankrupt
yeah it's been incredibly devastating it
was it was my father died at the same
time wasn't that much inheritance
what little inheritance was went to pay
the creditors I mean it's it was more of
a symbolic thing I had nothing and is
that why you're here that you in a sense
went as far away as you possibly could
from from that world yep
Douglas visited Ecuador as a tourist and
wound up moving to the Amazon in 1991 he
started what's now called the Econo
foundation a network of education and
social service programs aimed at
preserving both the health of the
rainforest and of the people who live in
it I booked a room at the Econo eco
lodge opened in 1995 the lodge is one of
a couple of profit-making centers which
fund the Foundation's efforts over the
years these include a health clinic
educational projects and their forest
reserve of 4,300 acres but Douglas also
thinks small like this micro enterprise
project let's walk over here where the
cacao seedlings are so how does this end
up saving the rainforest okay these are
all cacao seedlings cacao or cocoa as we
know it is used to make chocolate and it
can be a valuable cash crop the people
have to make a living
they can either chop down about 50 acres
of forest to put pasture land or they
can chop down about five acres of
rainforest
and raise cacao and get the same income
so this is what people have to realize
when you're talking about quote unquote
saving the rainforest it doesn't mean
just locking it all up and not touching
it
people live here we have to recognize
that they have to make a living and this
is why our whole focus is on education
so the people can learn how to do things
in a better way that's good with that
goal in mind we visited the foundation's
latest development this is the China
Technical High School this is a school
where the students learn by doing it's
hands-on education with lessons more
often taught in the jungle than in the
classrooms
that said they've just put in a full
computer lab we are strong believer of
bridging the digital divide the kids are
all learning how to use internet they
browse they are communicating we're in
the process of setting up a blog it has
to start from the bottom up and that's
what we're doing
the idea is to educate the people who
live in the rainforest about the value
of their own environment the world's
rainforests are now disappearing at the
rate of a football-sized clearing every
second of every day one-fifth of carbon
emissions now come from this V
forestation
and preserving that forest should be the
low-hanging fruit in the war on climate
change people like Juan have emerged as
agents of change in their own
communities helping to preserve what's
left I know it's difficult now it's very
difficult but still with the help of
education on so so forth we can we can
make a difference
I think Douglas and Juan are onto
something there are people from
different worlds but they've got a
simple model for helping the rainforest
survive and giving me a glimmer of hope
for its future in the Amazon for the new
york times i'm nicholas kristoff
